thread.title: 'We wish EU a merry Christmas': Anti-Brexit protesters call for second referendum - with carols

author: Hannah Graham
title: 'We wish EU a merry Christmas': Anti-Brexit protesters call for second referendum - with carols
text:

Carol singers descended on Northumberland Street on Friday night - hoping their songs would bring an end to Brexit . 
With lyrics ranging from “on the first day of Christmas, the EU gave to me / a trade treaty for our country” to “we wish EU a merry Christmas”, singers said they were hoping to remind people that leaving the European Union is not yet ‘a done deal’ – despite EU leaders having signed off the first phase of the negotiations. 
Organiser Silvie Fisch said: “We just wanted to say we are still here, we are still opposed to Brexit, we still believe it doesn’t have to happen, and it’s bad for our country. 
“It’s just a shambles, the way it’s being handled. 
“People say it was ‘the will of the people’ but that’s just not true: it was so close, and people were misinformed and misled. 
“We want to have another referendum now, and see what people think now.” Anti-Brexit campaigners taking part in a Christmas carol-themed flash mob on Northumberland Street (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Silvie, who is originally from Germany but has lived in the North East for 20 years, says the referendum vote came as a “huge shock” to her. 
She said: “I honestly still can’t believe it. 
“I brought my mum here to live with me just before the vote, she’s 81 and it’s been a big worry for her. Read More 
“It makes you feel strange - you look around and think, do these people like me? I’ve never had that before - I’ve always felt welcome and safe.” 
Fellow protestor Bill Corcoran added: “We went into it when the terms weren’t known. Anti-Brexit campaigners taking part in a Christmas carol-themed flash mob on Northumberland Street (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
“Speaking from the Irish community’s perspective, we haven’t worked so hard over the years on peace to have it ripped apart and have a border imposed. 
“We need another vote. Leaving the EU is unjust, and apart from anything else, from an economic perspective it’s a bad idea. 
“A bus told me we would have £350 million a week for the NHS, but now I hear it’s going to cost £45 billion to leave - people might think they’ve backed the wrong bus.” Like us on Facebook
